<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 306, 220, 321]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 304, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Mechanics 2 (M2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 787, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 384, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 540, 285, 555]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 555, 910, 585]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 585, 724, 600]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 600, 593, 615]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 615, 606, 630]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 644, 608, 660]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 660, 756, 675]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 675, 440, 690]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A small ball is projected with speed \(15 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) above the horizontal. Find the distance from the point of projection of the ball at the instant when it is travelling horizontally. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is projected with speed \(20 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) below the horizontal, from a point \(O\) which is \(30 \mathrm{~m}\) above horizontal ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 156, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 561, 138]]<|/det|>
Calculate the time taken by \(P\) to reach the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 154, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Calculate the speed and direction of motion of \(P\) immediately before it reaches the ground. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[363, 85, 670, 250]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 268, 920, 303]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a uniform lamina \(ABCD\) with \(AB = 0.75 \text{m}\), \(AD = 0.6 \text{m}\) and \(BC = 0.9 \text{m}\). Angle \(BAD = \text{angle } ABC = 90^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 316, 156, 333]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 316, 920, 348]]<|/det|>
Show that the distance of the centre of mass of the lamina from \(AB\) is \(0.38 \text{m}\), and find the distance of the centre of mass from \(BC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 331, 920, 348]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 85, 631, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 252, 920, 351]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(P\) and \(Q\) have masses \(0.4 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(m \mathrm{kg}\) respectively. \(P\) is attached to a fixed point \(A\) by a light inextensible string of length \(0.5 \mathrm{m}\) which is inclined at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) to the vertical. \(P\) and \(Q\) are joined to each other by a light inextensible vertical string. \(Q\) is attached to a fixed point \(B\), which is vertically below \(A\), by a light inextensible string. The string \(BQ\) is taut and horizontal. The particles rotate in horizontal circles about an axis through \(A\) and \(B\) with constant angular speed \(\omega\) rad s \(^{- 1}\) (see diagram). The tension in the string joining \(P\) and \(Q\) is \(1.5 \mathrm{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 363, 153, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 363, 574, 381]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the string \(AP\) and the value of \(\omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 363, 920, 381]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
\(O\) and \(A\) are fixed points on a rough horizontal surface, with \(O A = 1 \mathrm{~m}\). A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.4 \mathrm{~kg}\) is projected horizontally with speed \(U \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) from \(A\) in the direction \(O A\) and moves in a straight line. After projection, when the displacement of \(P\) from \(O\) is \(x \mathrm{~m}\), the velocity of \(P\) is \(v \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\). The coefficient of friction between the surface and \(P\) is 0.4. A force of magnitude \(\frac{0.8}{x} \mathrm{~N}\) acts on \(P\) in the direction \(PO\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 183, 154, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 180, 616, 203]]<|/det|>
Show that, while the particle is in motion, \(\mathrm{v}\frac{\mathrm{d}\mathrm{v}}{\mathrm{d}x} = - 4 - \frac{2}{x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 184, 917, 203]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 425, 707, 445]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(P\) comes to instantaneous rest between \(x = 2.0\) and \(x = 2.1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 462, 154, 480]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 462, 448, 480]]<|/det|>
Find the set of possible values of \(U\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 463, 920, 482]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
One end of a light elastic string of natural length \(0.6 \text{m}\) and modulus of elasticity \(24 \text{N}\) is attached to a fixed point \(O\). The other end of the string is attached to a particle \(P\) of mass \(0.4 \text{kg}\) which hangs in equilibrium vertically below \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 135, 452, 153]]<|/det|>
Calculate the extension of the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 345, 801, 367]]<|/det|>
\(P\) is projected vertically downwards from the equilibrium position with speed \(5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 377, 153, 395]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 377, 707, 395]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance \(P\) travels before it is first at instantaneous rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 377, 920, 395]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 875, 92]]<|/det|>
When \(P\) is first at instantaneous rest a stationary particle of mass \(0.4 \mathrm{kg}\) becomes attached to \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 153, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 104, 751, 122]]<|/det|>
Find the greatest speed of the combined particle in the subsequent motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
